Philo-Xenia
 
 In regard to Philo-Xenia, I cannot offer a precise definition, I can only tell an old family tale.
 
 My grandparents on my mother's side migrated to what was South Dakota in the very early 20th century.
 
 My grandmother was largely unschooled, literate, but keen and intelligent and diligent in exposing her children to the love of reading and good literature, as she in her poorly educated state could determine.
 
 Another aspect of my grandmother's personality was the old custom of extended kindness and hospitality to strangers. This was exemplified in her extension of her household's hospitality to a traveling Arab pedlar. This fellow was feared by our neighbors, the inherent xenophobia of the exclusively white population of that time. He was dark. He had a strange accent and strange ways that did not resonate with what they recognized as human company, he very likely WAS NOT A CHRISTIAN.
 
 My grandmother welcomed this man when he passed through the region and she was probably the only Dakotan of that time who was brave enough and principled to extend this welcoming to him.
 
 Some years later, after her death, the pedlar again passed through that region again. When he learned of her death he was profoundly silent and wept bitterly at her death. The death of a very fine and principled person.
